stream_context.summary: Kaze works on a large factory level, implementing a new seesaw mechanic with a Goomba and modeling a construction worker Whomp. A significant portion of the stream is dedicated to testing the level's performance on N64 hardware, diagnosing a compiler bug, and optimizing the framerate via backface culling.

development_findings.summary: Kaze successfully optimized a level for N64 by enabling backface culling on specific materials, raising the framerate from 19 to 25 FPS in demanding scenes.
development_findings.quote: This was 19. 25. Dude, I predicted this exact number. That's a lot better.

development_findings.summary: Kaze diagnosed and fixed a critical N64 crash caused by an aggressive compiler optimization (delay slot pipelining) that bypassed his safety check for a division-by-zero error.
development_findings.quote: Basically, the compiler decided that right here, where I want to avoid the division by 0, it is going to pipeline the division into the delay slot of my branch. So that no matter what happens, I always divide by 0.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a new seesaw mechanic where the player can trigger it to fall and flatten a Goomba, spending time to fine-tune the physics-based animation until it felt perfect.
development_findings.quote: Alright, the final image is beautiful. Like it ending like this is the best thing ever. I love this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has implemented significant improvements to the game's collision system, making it much more stable on complex surfaces than the original Mario 64 engine.
development_findings.quote: You see how stable that is? Mario 64 would never be able to handle this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze modeled a new construction-themed Whomp, deciding to place its helmet on its back to serve as a clear weak point, consistent with the design of other Mario enemies.
The theme and lore of the factory level are evolving organically during development, shifting from a manufacturing plant to more of a refueling depot.
development_findings.quote: It was supposed to be like Bozo's Fleet Factory at first, but it slowly became just like the place where they tank up, I guess.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decides to have different visual settings for emulators versus real hardware, keeping backface culling disabled on emulators for his preferred aesthetic but enabling it on N64 for performance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally streams on a secondary channel to cultivate a dedicated community focused on development, rather than chasing algorithms or general entertainment on his main channel.
context_findings.quote: My streams here and they are like all about the game if you get entertained that's a side effect I just care about making a good game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels overwhelmed with commitments, including the main project, a side project for a competition, and a presentation for a tech conference.
context_findings.quote: Man i'm so busy actually I will never have my freedom.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals that his YouTube income is minimal, particularly after a major sponsorship deal ended, highlighting the financial precarity of his work.
context_findings.quote: My youtube channel Is barely profitable, especially now that brilliant doesn't sponsor me anymore kind of back to square zero.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that code should be written so clearly that it is self-explanatory, making separate documentation redundant.
context_findings.quote: The code itself is better documentation than your documentation so you should remove your documentation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prefers level design where worlds are distinct and connected via an overworld, rather than being directly interconnected, to avoid player backtracking.
context_findings.quote: Having it the way Banjo-Tooie did it means you add a lot of backtracking and I don't like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with YouTube's high stream delay, despite using the 'low latency' setting, and notes his viewership has not yet recovered to the levels he had on Twitch.

biobak.summary: Kaze shares a moment of friendly banter with Biobak, acknowledging that the stream's primary goal is development, with entertainment being secondary.
biobak.quote: It's neat for me sad for you. This is that fair assessment of the situation.

badub.summary: Kaze notes that Badub, the composer, has been temporarily unavailable, which has left the music for a new enemy unplanned.
badub.quote: I thought Badub was gonna make him song but Badub's been missing in attendance for a bit so I'm not really sure what to expect there.

zeina.summary: Zeina has created animations for the 'cement pit guy' enemy, which are ready for Kaze to implement.
Kaze makes a playful comment about Zeina, suggesting a personal dynamic related to the game's characters.
zeina.quote: I touched her right in the Yoshi. She would not let anyone else touch the Yoshi.

key_stories.title: N64 Performance Optimization
key_stories.summary: Kaze diagnosed a severe performance issue on N64 hardware and solved it by selectively enabling backface culling. This technical fix saved the level's design and resulted in a hybrid approach to visuals, with different settings for console and emulator.
key_stories.challenge: A large, complex factory level was running at an unacceptably low framerate (19 FPS) on real N64 hardware, threatening its viability.
key_stories.process: Kaze tested the level on an N64, identified the specific camera angles causing the worst lag, and hypothesized that rendering the back-sides of metal scaffolding was the cause. He enabled backface culling on those materials, recompiled, and ran another test to confirm the significant performance gain.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully increased the framerate to a playable 25-29 FPS by enabling backface culling for the N64 build. He decided to make this a hardware-specific optimization, preserving his preferred visual style on emulators.
key_stories.key_quote: This was 19. 25. Dude, I predicted this exact number. That's a lot better.

key_stories.title: The Compiler Delay Slot Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze encountered a game-breaking crash on N64 and discovered it was caused by an obscure compiler quirk, not a bug in his own logic. He had to 'outsmart' the compiler by reordering his code to fix the issue, demonstrating a deep level of technical expertise.
key_stories.challenge: The game was crashing on N64 with a division-by-zero error, even though Kaze's code contained a check to prevent that exact scenario.
key_stories.process: After the crash, Kaze analyzed the function and realized the compiler was executing the division instruction in the 'delay slot' of his conditional check. This meant the division always occurred, regardless of the check. He had to manually restructure the code to prevent this pipelining.
key_stories.outcome: By reordering the code instructions, Kaze worked around the compiler's aggressive optimization, fixed the crash, and was able to continue testing on hardware. The incident showcases the deep, non-obvious technical hurdles of N64 development.
key_stories.key_quote: That's not a bug in the code. That is not my fault. So I need to move some of these computations into new slots like this.

key_stories.title: The Seesaw Goomba Set-Piece
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed and implemented a custom physics animation for a seesaw that crushes a Goomba. Through a process of iterative refinement, he turned a simple idea into a polished and humorous in-game event.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to create a unique, satisfying environmental interaction where the player could make a seesaw crush a Goomba.
key_stories.process: Kaze designed the trigger (breaking a box) and then iteratively scripted the seesaw's fall. He adjusted variables for rotation speed, gravity, and bounce, and programmed the Goomba to detach and fall realistically to be squished underneath the plank.
key_stories.outcome: After numerous tweaks to the animation script, Kaze created a complete and polished set-piece that he was extremely proud of, achieving the desired comedic and interactive effect.
key_stories.key_quote: Alright, the final image is beautiful. Like it ending like this is the best thing ever. I love this.
